citations.narrative:
A bag of dog food was observed to be stored on the floor in an outdoor run of the kennel. The licensee stated he was not
going to be using that food and was going to be getting rid of it. Dog food stored on the ground has the potential to attract
rodents. All bags of dog food must be stored up off the ground and away from the walls to allow for cleaning underneath
and around the food supplies. Correct by 4/5/23.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The licensee recently had a mouse infestation. He used baits and traps to eliminate the mice. He did not however clean
up all the mice feces that can easily be found throughout the kennel. Mouse feces was observed on top of enclosures, in
empty enclosures, and in the trays underneath at least one of the enclosures. In addition, clutter was observed on top of
some of the enclosures and in empty enclosures (inside and outside runs).
While the mice may be gone, the feces that has been left behind still has the potential to transmit disease. In addition, the
presence of the mouse feces makes it difficult for the licensee to know if the mice have come back after being eliminated.
The clutter found throughout the kennel offer mice opportunities for shelter and some of the clutter provides bedding for
the mice.
The licensee has to clean up the clutter and mouse feces found throughout the kennel.
Correct by 4/11/23.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
End of report.
n

narrative:
3.1(e) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
A bag of dog food was observed to be stored on the floor in an outdoor run of the kennel.  The licensee stated he was not 
going to be using that food and was going to be getting rid of it.  Dog food stored on the ground has the potential to attract 
rodents.  All bags of dog food must be stored up off the ground and away from the walls to allow for cleaning underneath 
and around the food supplies.  Correct by 4/5/23. 
3.11(c) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The licensee recently had a mouse infestation.  He used baits and traps to eliminate the mice.  He did not however clean 
up all the mice feces that can easily be found throughout the kennel.  Mouse feces was observed on top of enclosures, in 
empty enclosures, and in the trays underneath at least one of the enclosures.  In addition, clutter was observed on top of 
some of the enclosures and in empty enclosures (inside and outside runs). 
 
While the mice may be gone, the feces that has been left behind still has the potential to transmit disease.  In addition, the 
presence of the mouse feces makes it difficult for the licensee to know if the mice have come back after being eliminated.  
The clutter found throughout the kennel offer mice opportunities for shelter and some of the clutter provides bedding for 
the mice.

The licensee has to clean up the clutter and mouse feces found throughout the kennel. 
 
Correct by 4/11/23. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
End of report. 
 
 n
